title: Hard Feedback to a High Performer
situation: A strong performer has started interrupting others more often in meetings. They may not see the impact.
question: How do you give them feedback?

choices.label: Say nothing because you don’t want to upset one of your best people.
choices.outcome: The interruptions continue, and quieter voices contribute less.
choices.insight: Avoiding feedback to keep short-term comfort often harms the broader team over time.

choices.label: Say, “I really value your ideas, and I’ve also noticed you’re jumping in quickly in meetings. I’m worried others are holding back. Can we experiment with you pausing once before speaking?”
choices.outcome: They understand the behavior and its impact, and you make it clear you’re on their side.
choices.insight: Effective feedback ties observed behavior to impact and offers a concrete adjustment to try.

choices.label: Tell them, “You’re being rude in meetings,” in front of the whole team.
choices.outcome: They feel embarrassed and may shut down or get defensive.
choices.insight: Public shaming usually creates fear, not growth.
